awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: CAREER: Catalytic Methods for Direct Access to Tetrasubstituted Nitrogen-Containing Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis (CAT) Program in the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Catharine H. Larsen at the University of California, Riverside. The project focuses on developing a new series of catalysts to prepare amine-bearing tetrasubstituted carbon centers in a single, efficient, catalytic process. The reactions minimize waste with the sole by-product being one equivalent of water. The resulting molecular building blocks form the core of therapeutic natural products, biomedical probes, and pharmaceuticals. The outreach activities integrate green chemistry principles, bringing chemistry to students and the wider public through art.

Professor Larsen's project develops a one-step catalytic methods to synthesize amine-bearing tetrasubstituted carbon centers. A dual metal system is being used to overcome the high energy barrier required in forming key molecular intermediates for direct access to highly hindered compounds. The approach uses sustainable catalysts to access asymmetric, tetrasubstituted carbons in a single step to provide hindered organic amines. Professor Larsen showcases the influence of green chemistry and catalysis through lectures, laboratory courses, presentations to the Women in Science Engaging Riverside (WISER) club, and "The Science of Art" program, which is integrated into the Riverside Art Museum's "Walk and Wonder" tours. The latter outreach inspires socioeconomically disadvantaged 2nd- and 5th-grade students through tactile experimentation with the chemistry involved in the creation of paintings, sculptures, and other media, providing a positive reaction to science.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Our research is focused on new catalytic methods to access tetrasubstituted carbons bearing nitrogen directly from commercially available starting materials.  These crowded amines form the core of therapeutic natural products, biomedical probes, and pharmaceuticals, but are generally accessed via multistep syntheses requiring a larger mass of metals than that of the products formed. Furthermore, these alpha-tetrasubstituted amines are more stable and can display higher activities than their less-hindered counterparts.  Rapid, facile access to compounds of interest for medicinal testing enables drug discovery and reduces environmental waste.  One step, catalytic reactions to access relatively complex structures directly from purchased starting materials also facilitate large scale pharmaceutical processes.

By studying and understanding the mechanisms by which these reactions operate, we have developed new methods to synthesize new hindered alpha-tetrasubstituted amines by both classic condensation and novel hydroamination routes.  Impressively, these innovations are the result of solvent-free methods involving tiny amounts of inexpensive metals.  By shifting the paradigm from multiple metals over many steps to titanium in a single step, the reaction produces non-toxic by-products:  water, ethanol, and titanium dioxide (sunscreen).

To address another area with unrealized potential, gold(III) complexes bearing heterocyclic amine ligands were synthesized and tested as catalysts.  In stark contrast with over 30 years of asymmetric gold(I) chemistry, more reactive/acidic gold(III) is rarely used in conjunction with a ligand framework?let alone a chiral ligand that would allow for the formation of a single enantiomer required for testing by the FDA.  Thus, to open the arena of enantioselective gold(III)-catalyzed reactions first required the synthesis, characterization, and testing gold(III) complexes bearing any ligand support.  These nitrogen-containing ligands were themselves obtained by green methods, including our new one-step, solvent-free, and metal-free synthesis of substituted pyridyl quinolines.  To access more stable gold complexes, we streamlined known methods to form pyridyl triazoles (PyTri) while broadening the scope to tunable, substituted PyTri ligands. These heterocyclic, aromatic ligands produce catalytically active complexes with both palladium and gold.

Students trained in this arena of organic chemistry develop both an understanding of what structural motifs represent important target molecules and how to approach them using sustainable methods. These environmentally friendly methods to form important pharmacophores are an ideal platform for incorporating green chemistry into the undergraduate laboratory curriculum.

Partnering with the Riverside Art Museum allowed the PI to adapt "The Science of Art" talks into chemistry-based explanations of elementary school art projects for disadvantaged children.


Last Modified: 03/06/2023
Modified by: Catharine H Larsen
